hints_html:
The given differential equation satisfies exponential growth.

The solution of the differential equation \(\frac{dy}{dt} = ky\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y(t) = y(0) \cdot e^{kt}\end{aligned}\]
hints_latex: The given differential equation satisfies exponential growth.
hints_raw:
The given differential equation satisfies exponential growth.
The solution of the differential equation <math>\frac{dy}{dt} = ky</math> is 
:<math>\displaystyle y(t) = y(0) \cdot e^{kt}</math>
question: B 07
sols_html:
The solution of the differential equation \(\frac{dy}{dt} = ky\) is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y(t) = y(0) \cdot e^{kt}\end{aligned}\]

where in this case \(y\) is the number of viral particles, \(t\) is the time in days, and \(k\) is some constant.

We are given that \(\displaystyle y(0) = 1000,\, k = 0.05\). Thus we have \(\displaystyle y(t) = 1000e^{0.05t}\).

Solving for \(t\) when \(\displaystyle y(t) = 350000\) yields:

\[\begin{aligned} 350000 &= 1000e^{0.05t} \\ 350 &= e^{0.05t} \\ \ln350 &= 0.05t \\ t &= {\color{blue} \frac{\ln350}{0.05} \,\,\mathrm{days}}\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Initially, a patient has \(1000\) copies of the HIV virus. If the smallest detectable viral load is \(350,000\) virus particles, how long (in days) will it take until the HIV infection is detectable? Assume that the number of virus particles y grows according to the equation

\(\frac{dy}{dt} = 0.05y\)

where t is time in days. Leave your answer in terms of logarithms.
statement_latex:
Initially, a patient has $1000$ copies of the HIV virus. If the smallest
detectable viral load is $350,000$ virus particles, how long (in days)
will it take until the HIV infection is detectable? Assume that the
number of virus particles \emph{y} grows according to the equation

$\frac{dy}{dt} = 0.05y$

where \emph{t} is time in days. Leave your answer in terms of
logarithms.
statement_raw:
Initially, a patient has <math>1000</math> copies of the HIV virus.  If the smallest detectable viral load is <math>350,000</math> virus particles, how long (in days) will it take until the HIV infection is detectable?  Assume that the number of virus particles ''y'' grows according to the equation

<math>\frac{dy}{dt} = 0.05y</math>

where ''t'' is time in days.  Leave your answer in terms of logarithms.
